@hachikuji : Thanks for the latest patch. LGTM. I will let you merge it.

As @guozhangwang has pointed out "it is tricky to synchronize the expiration inside RocksDB along with the corresponding changelog truncation".
If we do not do this, we have to do what @mjsax has suggested.
"In recovery case, we only need to make sure to not reread old (i.e, already expired) record that got not yet deleted back into TtlDB."

I was thinking we can have special key types which have the ttl in the key itself. For eg. we can have avro keys with special ttl field. Or string key which end with _ttlxxxx. This does look ugly but this way we avoid having to maintain a separate state to keep track of which records are expired, which IMO is a huge gain !

@guozhangwang The difference between `FATAL_ERROR` and `ABORTABLE_ERROR` is that the former state will throw an exception back at the user even if they try to call `abortTransaction()`. The only possible recovery is closing the producer (see related issue https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-5342). In some cases, we may reach an abortable error before any partition has been successfully added to the transaction (this is unfortunately the consequence of not having a BeginTxn request). We want the user to call `abortTransaction()` in this case, but we want to avoid sending EndTxn since this would cause an invalid transaction state.

I've been thinking about the current patch for a while and finally it LGTM. The subtle thing is the fact that we'll keep retrying AddPartition failures as long as we get retriable errors. If we receive an abortable error, we'll stop retrying and the EndTxn should reach the head of the queue. Luckily we made the AddPartitions request have all or nothing semantics, so any failure would mean we haven't started the transaction (assuming there were no previous successes).

@apurvam Please review when you have a chance. I don't think this is a blocker. If we receive an abortable error in AddPartitions, we don't add the partitions back to the pending set. And since they were already moved from the new partitions set, we won't add them back to the queue in `nextRequestHandler`. Nevertheless, there are a few cleanups in here which might be worth having.
@vahidhashemian Thanks for the patch. Please rebase when you have a chance.
Apologies, will close this PR and submit a KIP for consideration.

@becketqin : Thanks for the patch. Sorry for late review. It does seem that this adds quite a bit complexity and will be a bit hard to reason about. So, I agree that the easiest thing is to just revert the changes in KAFKA-4340 and default message.timestamp.difference.max.ms back to Long.MaxValue. Without KAFKA-4340, in the worse case, it seems that every other segment could be rolled with just a single message in it. It's not ideal, but probably won't break things immediately. The users can always explicitly override the config if desired. Do you think you could submit a patch to default message.timestamp.difference.max.ms back to Long.MaxValue in the next few days for the 0.11.0.0 release?
Triggering some more retests to see if it's stable (as we got one test failure above but no Stacktrace -- unclear what the problem might be.)
Retest this please.

> But a duplicate would be ok (ie, at-least-once) -- right now, we could loose records.

It is not only duplicate record right? Say if you have a groupBy aggregation processor which consumes from `topic2` above we would encounter the same issue, that is we deduct on the aggregatekey of `a:0` twice and add on `a:1` twice, which is incorrect results.

@hejiefang Thanks for the patch. Merged to trunk.

Moving forward for small fixes like this one you do not need to create JIRA but can just submit a PR titled "MINOR: fix..."
Could you update `ROCKSDB_CONFIG_SETTER_CLASS_DOC` to update the documentation accordingly as I mentioned before?

@umesh9794 Thanks for picking it up.

We generally would not recommend "fixing" a unit test by adding sleep time, as it simply adds non-deterministic timing dependency on the unit test, hence the test will become more flaky on different environments.

If you believe the root cause of the issue is indeed because of metadata not propagated in time, consider using `TestUtils.waitUntilMetadataIsPropagated`, and try running the unit test with / wo your patch on a "slow environment" e.g. 1 CPU, small memory, to demonstrate that "wo the patch the test fails X times every 100 runs, and with the patch the test never fail for 1000 runs" etc.

You can take a look at some other flaky unit test PRs for reference.

Failed with
```
java.lang.AssertionError: Condition not met within timeout 60000. Should receive uncaught exception from one StreamThread.
	at org.apache.kafka.test.TestUtils.waitForCondition(TestUtils.java:274)
	at org.apache.kafka.streams.integration.EosIntegrationTest.shouldNotViolateEosIfOneTaskFails(EosIntegrationTest.java:406)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
```

@guozhangwang Is this the same exception from the failure above you reported?

That it true -- but it's "at-least-once", isn't it? I mean, if you apply a regular `stream.groupByKey.count()` we could also over count. And applying a deduce twice is also a duplicate -- but not applying it, is data loss. At least from my understanding.

The ultimate fix is EOS anyway... The question is, if the current behavior break "at-least-once" or not IMHO -- with "at-least-once" we cannot guarantee an exact result in case of failure anyway.
cc @junrao @ijuma This is a back-port of the changes merged to trunk.
